analyzed: sukhumālaḥ aha bhikkhave parama sukhumālaḥ accanta sukhumālaḥ
translated: “I was delicate, monks, extremely delicate, supremely delicate.

original: Mama sudaṁ, bhikkhave, pitu nivesane pokkharaṇiyo kāritā honti.
analyzed: mama suda bhikkhave pitu nivesane pokkharaṇiyaḥ kāritāḥ honti
translated: In my father’s house there were lotus ponds made:

original: Ekattha sudaṁ, bhikkhave, uppalaṁ vappati, ekattha padumaṁ, ekattha puṇḍarīkaṁ, yāvadeva mamatthāya.
analyzed: ekattha suda bhikkhave uppalam vappati ekattha padume ekattha puṇḍarīka yāvat eva mamatthāya
translated: in one pond there were blue lotuses, in one there were red lotuses, in one there were white lotuses, just for me.

original: Na kho panassāhaṁ, bhikkhave, akāsikaṁ candanaṁ dhāremi. Kāsikaṁ, bhikkhave, su me taṁ veṭhanaṁ hoti, kāsikā kañcukā, kāsikaṁ nivāsanaṁ, kāsiko uttarāsaṅgo.
analyzed: na kho panassa āha bhikkhave a kāsikam candanam dhāremi kāsika bhikkhave su me tam veṭhanam hoti kāsikā kañcukā kāsikam nivāsana kāsikaḥ uttarāsaṅgaḥ
translated: I didn’t wear any but Kāsi cloth: my turban was of Kāsi cloth, my outer cloak of Kāsi cloth, my lower garments of Kāsi cloth, my turban-wrap of Kāsi cloth.

original: Rattindivaṁ kho pana me su taṁ, bhikkhave, setacchattaṁ dhārīyati:
analyzed: rattindivam kho pana me bhikkhave seta chattam dhārīyati
translated: A white sunshade was held over me day and night:

original: ‘mā naṁ phusi sītaṁ vā uṇhaṁ vā tiṇaṁ vā rajo vā ussāvo vā’ti.
analyzed: mā nam phusi sītam vā uṇham vā tiṇam vā rajaḥ vā ussāvaḥ vāti
translated: ‘So that neither cold nor heat nor dust nor dirt gets on him.’

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, bhikkhave, tayo pāsādā ahesuṁ—eko hemantiko, eko gimhiko, eko vassiko.
analyzed: tassa bhikkhave tayo pāsādāḥ ahesu ekaḥ hemantikaḥ ekaḥ gimhikaḥ ekaḥ vassikaḥ
translated: I had three palaces, one for the rainy season, one for the winter, one for the summer.

original: So kho ahaṁ, bhikkhave, vassike pāsāde vassike cattāro māse nippurisehi tūriyehi paricārayamāno na heṭṭhāpāsādaṁ orohāmi.
analyzed: saḥ kho aha bhikkhave vassike pāsāde vassike cattāraḥ māse nippurisehi tūriyehi paricārayamānaḥ na heṭṭhā pāsādam orohāmi
translated: and the musicians entertained me without leaving the mansion.🔽But while I was being entertained by the musicians, I thought:

original: Yathā kho pana, bhikkhave, aññesaṁ nivesane dāsakammakaraporisassa kaṇājakaṁ bhojanaṁ
analyzed: yathā kho pana bhikkhave aññesam nivesane dāsa kammakara porisassa kaṇājakam
translated: ‘In other people’s houses, the servants and workers are given🔽coarse food of beans and sesame,

original: dīyati bilaṅgadutiyaṁ, evamevassu me, bhikkhave, pitu nivesane dāsakammakaraporisassa🔽sālimaṁsodano dīyati.
analyzed: dīyati bilaṅga dutiye me bhikkhave pitu nivesane dāsa kammakara porisassa  sālimasodanaḥ dīyati
translated: but in my father’s house they were given rice and meat.

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, bhikkhave, evarūpāya iddhiyā samannāgatassa evarūpena ca sukhumālena etadahosi:
analyzed: tassa bhikkhave evarūpāya iddhiyā samannāgatassa evarūpena ca sukhu mālena etat ahosi
translated: ‘And, monks, with such psychic power and such delicacy of perception, I thought:

original: ‘assutavā kho puthujjano attanā jarādhammo samāno jaraṁ anatīto paraṁ jiṇṇaṁ disvā aṭṭīyati harāyati jigucchati attānaṁyeva atisitvā, ahampi khomhi jarādhammo jaraṁ anatīto.
analyzed: assutavā kho puthujjanaḥ attanā jarā dhammo samānaḥ jaram an atītaḥ param jiṇṇam disvā aṭṭīyati harāyati jigucchati attā anayā iva atisitvā aham pi kho mhi jarā dhammaḥ jaram an atītaḥ
translated: ‘An uneducated ordinary person like myself might see an old person and think: “It will not happen to me, it will not happen to me!” But it will happen.

original: Ahañceva kho pana jarādhammo samāno jaraṁ anatīto paraṁ jiṇṇaṁ disvā aṭṭīyeyyaṁ harāyeyyaṁ jiguccheyyaṁ na metaṁ assa patirūpan’ti.
analyzed: aham ca iva kho pana jarā dhammo samānaḥ jaram anatītaḥ param jiṇṇam disvā aṭṭīyeyyam harāyeyyam jiguccheyyam na mā etam assa patirūpanti
translated: If I, who am subject to old age and cannot escape it, were to be horrified, humiliated, and disgusted by this, that would not be fitting for me.’

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, bhikkhave, iti paṭisañcikkhato yo yobbane yobbanamado so sabbaso pahīyi.🔽Assutavā kho puthujjano attanā byādhidhammo samāno byādhiṁ anatīto paraṁ byādhitaṁ disvā aṭṭīyati harāyati jigucchati attānaṁyeva atisitvā:
analyzed: tassa bhikkhave iti paṭisañcikkhataḥ yaḥ yobbane yobbana madaḥ so sabbasas pahīyi  a sutavā kho puthujjanaḥ attanā byādhi dhammo samānaḥ byādhim an atītaḥ param byādhitam disvā aṭṭīyati harāyati jigucchati attā anayā iva atisitvā
translated: As I reflected thus, the intoxication with youth subsided.🔽“An untaught ordinary person, bhikkhus, on seeing a sick person, is horrified, humiliated, and disgusted, thinking: ‘Oh, how painful is sickness! Oh, how unpleasant is sickness! Oh, how hard it is to have sickness!’

original: ‘ahampi khomhi byādhidhammo byādhiṁ anatīto, ahañceva kho pana byādhidhammo samāno
analyzed: aham pi khomhi byādhi dhammaḥ byādhim anatītaḥ aham ca iva kho pana byādhi dhammaḥ samānaḥ
translated: He does not see a sick person in himself,

original: byādhiṁ anatīto paraṁ byādhikaṁ disvā aṭṭīyeyyaṁ harāyeyyaṁ jiguccheyyaṁ, na metaṁ assa patirūpan’ti.
analyzed: byādhim an atītaḥ param byādhikam disvā aṭṭīyeyyam harāyeyyam jiguccheyya na mā etam assa patirūpanti
translated: and if he were to be horrified, humiliated, and disgusted by this, that would not be fitting for him.’

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, bhikkhave, iti paṭisañcikkhato yo ārogye ārogyamado so sabbaso pahīyi.
analyzed: tassa bhikkhave iti paṭisañcikkhataḥ yaḥ ārogye ārogya madaḥ so sabbaso pahīyi
translated: As I reflected thus, the intoxication with health subsided.

original: Assutavā kho puthujjano attanā maraṇadhammo samāno maraṇaṁ anatīto paraṁ mataṁ disvā aṭṭīyati harāyati jigucchati attānaṁyeva atisitvā:
analyzed: assutavā kho puthujjanaḥ attanā maraṇa dhammo samānaḥ maraṇam anatītaḥ param matam disvā aṭṭīyati harāyati jigucchati attā anayā iva atisitvā
translated: The uninstructed worldling, himself subject to death, not escaped from death, on seeing another who is dead, is frightened, is terrified, is gripped by fear:

original: ‘ahampi khomhi maraṇadhammo, maraṇaṁ anatīto, ahaṁ ceva kho pana maraṇadhammo samāno
analyzed: aham api khomhi maraṇa dhammaḥ maraṇam anatītaḥ aham ca iva kho pana maraṇa dhammaḥ samānaḥ
translated: ‘I am subject to death, I am not escaped from death.

original: maraṇaṁ anatīto paraṁ mataṁ disvā aṭṭīyeyyaṁ harāyeyyaṁ jiguccheyyaṁ, na metaṁ assa patirūpan’ti.
analyzed: maraṇam an atītaḥ param matam disvā aṭṭīyeyyam harāyeyyam jiguccheyya na mā etam assa patirūpanti
translated: If I were to grieve, it would only be to my own detriment.’

original: Tassa mayhaṁ, bhikkhave, iti paṭisañcikkhato yo jīvite jīvitamado so sabbaso pahīyīti.
analyzed: tassa bhikkhave iti paṭisañcikkhataḥ yaḥ jīvite jīvita mado so sabbaso pahīyi iti
translated: When I reflected thus, the intoxication with life that had arisen in me subsided.

original: Tayome, bhikkhave, madā.
analyzed: tayo me bhikkhave madāḥ
translated: “Bhikkhus, there are these three kinds of intoxication.

original: Katame tayo?🔽Yobbanamado, ārogyamado, jīvitamado.
analyzed: katame tayaḥ  ārogya madaḥ jīvita madaḥ
translated: What three?🔽Intoxication with youth, intoxication with health, and intoxication with life.

original: Yobbanamadamatto vā, bhikkhave, assutavā puthujjano kāyena duccaritaṁ carati, vācāya duccaritaṁ carati, manasā duccaritaṁ carati.
analyzed: yobbana mada mattaḥ vā bhikkhave assutavā puthujjanaḥ kāyena duccaritam carati vācāya duccaritam carati manasā duccaritam carati
translated: “Bhikkhus, when a person intoxicated with youth, health, and life conducts himself in body, speech, and mind,

original: So kāyena duccaritaṁ caritvā, vācāya duccaritaṁ caritvā, manasā duccaritaṁ caritvā kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā apāyaṁ duggatiṁ vinipātaṁ nirayaṁ upapajjati.
analyzed: saḥ kāyena duccaritam caritvā vācāya duccaritam caritvā manasā duccaritam caritvā kāyassa bhedā param maraṇā apāyam duggatim vinipātam nirayam upapajjati
translated: “Blinded by the intoxication of health, the uninstructed worldling engages in bodily misconduct, verbal misconduct, and mental misconduct.

original: Ārogyamadamatto vā, bhikkhave, assutavā puthujjano …pe…🔽jīvitamadamatto vā, bhikkhave, assutavā puthujjano kāyena duccaritaṁ carati, vācāya duccaritaṁ carati, manasā duccaritaṁ carati.
analyzed: ārogya mada mattaḥ vā bhikkhave assutavā puthujjanaḥ pe  jīvita mada mattaḥ vā bhikkhave assutavā puthujjanaḥ kāyena duccaritam carati vācāya duccaritam carati manasā duccaritam carati
translated: After death, he is reborn in a lower realm, a bad realm, a lower world, hell.🔽“Blinded by the intoxication of life, the uninstructed worldling engages in bodily misconduct, verbal misconduct, and mental misconduct.

original: So kāyena duccaritaṁ caritvā, vācāya duccaritaṁ caritvā, manasā duccaritaṁ caritvā kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā apāyaṁ duggatiṁ vinipātaṁ nirayaṁ upapajjati.
analyzed: saḥ kāyena duccaritam caritvā vācāya duccaritam caritvā manasā duccaritam caritvā kāyassa bhedā param maraṇā apāyam duggatim vinipātam nirayam upapajjati
translated: After death, he is reborn in a lower realm, a bad realm, a lower world, hell.

original: Yobbanamadamatto vā, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sikkhaṁ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattati.
analyzed: yobbana mada mattaḥ vā bhikkhave bhikkhu sikkham paccakkhāya hīnāya āvattati
translated: “Blinded by the intoxication of youth, a bhikkhu abandons the training and reverts to the lower life.

original: Ārogyamadamatto vā, bhikkhave, bhikkhu …pe…
analyzed: ārogya mada mattaḥ vā bhikkhave bhikkhu pe
translated: “Blinded by the intoxication of health …

original: jīvitamadamatto vā, bhikkhave, bhikkhu sikkhaṁ paccakkhāya hīnāyāvattatīti.
analyzed: jīvita mada mattaḥ vā bhikkhave bhikkhu sikkham paccakkhāya hīnāya āvattati iti
translated: “Blinded by the intoxication of life, a bhikkhu abandons the training and reverts to the lower life.”

original: Byādhidhammā jarādhammā,
analyzed: byādhi dhammā jarā dhammā
translated: Subject to illness, subject to old age,

original: atho maraṇadhammino;
analyzed: atho maraṇa dhammino
translated: and subject to death.

original: Yathādhammā tathāsantā,
analyzed: yathā adhammā tathā asantā
translated: They are as they are by nature,

original: jigucchanti puthujjanā.🔽Ahañce taṁ jiguccheyyaṁ,
analyzed: jigucchanti puthujjanā  aham ced tam jiguccheyya
translated: and ordinary people are disgusted.🔽If I were to be disgusted

original: evaṁdhammesu pāṇisu;
analyzed: eva dhammesu pāṇisu
translated: with living beings who are as they are by nature,

original: Na metaṁ patirūpassa,
analyzed: na mā etam patirūpassa
translated: that would not be proper for me,

original: mama evaṁ vihārino.
analyzed: mama evam vihārinaḥ
translated: living as I do.

original: Sohaṁ evaṁ viharanto,
analyzed: evam viharantaḥ
translated: Living like this,

original: ñatvā dhammaṁ nirūpadhiṁ;
analyzed: ñatvā dhammam
translated: knowing the Dhamma free from attachments,

original: Ārogye yobbanasmiñca,
analyzed: ārogye yobbanasmin ca
translated: I overcome any intoxication

original: jīvitasmiñca ye madā.
analyzed: jīvitasmin ca ye madāḥ
translated: with health, youth, and life.

original: Sabbe made abhibhosmi,
analyzed: sabbe made abhibhosmi
translated: I overcome all intoxication,

original: Nekkhamme daṭṭhu khemataṁ;
analyzed: nekkhamme daṭṭhu khemata
translated: seeing the safety of renunciation.

original: Tassa me ahu ussāho,
analyzed: tassa me ahu ussāhaḥ
translated: I have the energy

original: Nibbānaṁ abhipassato.
analyzed: nibbānam abhipassataḥ
translated: to see Nibbāna.

original: Nāhaṁ bhabbo etarahi,
analyzed: na aham bhabbaḥ etarahi
translated: I am not able now

original: Kāmāni paṭisevituṁ;
analyzed: kāmāni paṭisevitu
translated: to enjoy sensual pleasures.

original: Anivatti bhavissāmi,
analyzed: anivatti bhavissāmi
translated: I will not return,

original: Brahmacariyaparāyaṇo”ti.
analyzed: brahmacariya parāyaṇā iti
translated: but will live the spiritual life.”

original: Navamaṁ.
analyzed: navama
translated: The ninth.

original: Aṅguttara Nikāya 3.40
analyzed: aṅguttara nikāya
translated: The Book of the Tens

original: 4. Devadūtavagga
analyzed: deva dūta vagga
translated: The Devadūta Group

original: Ādhipateyyasutta
analyzed: ādhipateyya sutta
translated: The Overpowering

original: “Tīṇimāni, bhikkhave, ādhipateyyāni.
analyzed: tīṇi imāni bhikkhave ādhipateyyāni
translated: “Bhikkhus, there are these three things that overpower.

original: Katamāni tīṇi?
analyzed: katamāni tīṇi
translated: What three?

original: Attādhipateyyaṁ, lokādhipateyyaṁ, dhammādhipateyyaṁ.
analyzed: attā ādhipateyya loka ādhipateyya dhamma ādhipateyya
translated: The self as overpowering, the world as overpowering, and the Dhamma as overpowering.

original: Katamañca, bhikkhave, attādhipateyyaṁ?
analyzed: katamat ca bhikkhave attā ādhipateyya
translated: “And what, bhikkhus, is the self as overpowering?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu araññagato vā rukkhamūlagato vā suññāgāragato vā iti paṭisañcikkhati:
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu arañña gataḥ vā rukkha mūla gataḥ vā suññāgāra gataḥ vā iti paṭisañcikkhati
translated: “Here, bhikkhus, when gone to the forest, to the foot of a tree, or to an empty hut, a bhikkhu reflects thus:

original: ‘na kho panāhaṁ cīvarahetu agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajito.
analyzed: na kho pana aham cīvara hetu agārasmai anagāriyam pabbajitaḥ
translated: ‘I am not liberated from all suffering, yet I have not done what is needed to obtain complete freedom from suffeiing.

original: Na piṇḍapātahetu, na senāsanahetu, na itibhavābhavahetu agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajito.
analyzed: na piṇḍapāta hetu na senāsana hetu na iti bhava abhava hetu agārasma anagāriyam pabbajitaḥ
translated: I have not gone forth from the home life into homelessness to obtain robes, almsfood, resting place, and medicinal requisites,

original: Api ca khomhi otiṇṇo jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi, dukkhotiṇṇo dukkhapareto.
analyzed: api ca khomhi otiṇṇaḥ jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi dukkha utiṇṇaḥ dukkha paretaḥ
translated: but rather I have gone forth from the home life into homelessness to surmount the suffering, the non-ending of suffering.

original: Appeva nāma imassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa antakiriyā paññāyethāti.
analyzed: appā iva nāma imassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa anta kiriyā paññāyetha ati
translated: Perhaps the ending of this entire mass of suffering can be discerned!’

original: Ahañceva kho pana yādisake kāme ohāya agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajito tādisake vā kāme pariyeseyyaṁ tato vā pāpiṭṭhatare, na metaṁ patirūpan’ti.
analyzed: aham ca iva kho pana yādisake kāme ohāya agārasmaā anagāriyam pabbajitaḥ tādisake vā kāme pariyeseyyam tatas vā pāpiṭṭhatare na mā etam patirūpanti
translated: If I were to seek out such sensual pleasures as are inferior and crude, or sensual pleasures that are equal to those I formerly had when I lived at home, that would not be fitting for me.’

original: So iti paṭisañcikkhati:
analyzed: saḥ iti paṭisañcikkhati
translated: He reflects thus:

original: ‘āraddhaṁ kho pana me vīriyaṁ bhavissati asallīnaṁ, upaṭṭhitā sati asammuṭṭhā, passaddho kāyo asāraddho, samāhitaṁ cittaṁ ekaggan’ti.
analyzed: āraddham kho pana me vīriyam bhavissati a sallīna upaṭṭhitā sati a sammuṭṭhā passaddhaḥ kāyaḥ a sāraddhaḥ samāhitam cittam ekaggan ti
translated: ‘My persistence will be aroused & not lax; my mindfulness established & not confused; my body calm & not agitated; my mind centered & unified.’

original: So attānaṁyeva adhipatiṁ karitvā akusalaṁ pajahati, kusalaṁ bhāveti, sāvajjaṁ pajahati, anavajjaṁ bhāveti, suddhaṁ attānaṁ pariharati.
analyzed: saḥ attā anayā iva adhipatim karitvā akusalam pajahati kusalam bhāveti sāvajjam pajahati anavajjam bhāveti suddham attānam pariharati
translated: Making himself the master, he abandons what’s unskillful, develops what’s skillful, abandons what’s blameworthy, develops what’s beyond reproach, and looks after himself in a pure way.

original: Idaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, attādhipateyyaṁ.
analyzed: idam vuccati bhikkhave attādhipateyya
translated: This is called mastery of self.

original: Katamañca, bhikkhave, lokādhipateyyaṁ?
analyzed: katamat ca bhikkhave loka ādhipateyya
translated: “And what is mastery of the world?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu araññagato vā rukkhamūlagato vā suññāgāragato vā iti paṭisañcikkhati:🔽‘na kho panāhaṁ cīvarahetu agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajito.
analyzed: idha bhikkhave bhikkhu arañña gataḥ vā rukkha mūla gataḥ vā suññāgāra gataḥ vā iti paṭisañcikkhati  na kho pana aham cīvara hetu agārasmai anagāriyam pabbajitaḥ
translated: There is the case where a monk, having gone into the wilderness, to the root of a tree, or into an empty building, reflects:🔽‘I have not gone forth from the home life into homelessness for the sake of robes, almsfood, resting place, or medicinal requisites.

original: Na piṇḍapātahetu, na senāsanahetu, na itibhavābhavahetu agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajito.
analyzed: na piṇḍapāta hetu na senāsana hetu na iti bhava abhava hetu agārasma anagāriyam pabbajitaḥ
translated: But rather, having shaved off my hair & beard, having put on the saffron robes, I have gone forth from the home life into homelessness for the sake of unexcelled freedom from bondage.’

original: Api ca khomhi otiṇṇo jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi, dukkhotiṇṇo dukkhapareto.
analyzed: api ca khomhi otiṇṇaḥ jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi dukkha utiṇṇaḥ dukkha paretaḥ
translated: I am caught up in birth, aging, and death; in sorrow, lamentation, pain, displeasure, and despair; caught up in suffering, being burned by it, overcome by it.

original: Appeva nāma imassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa antakiriyā paññāyethā’ti.
analyzed: appā iva nāma imassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa anta kiriyā paññāyetha ati
translated: Perhaps an end to this whole mass of suffering can be known.’

original: Ahañceva kho pana evaṁ pabbajito samāno kāmavitakkaṁ vā vitakkeyyaṁ, byāpādavitakkaṁ vā vitakkeyyaṁ, vihiṁsāvitakkaṁ vā vitakkeyyaṁ, mahā kho panāyaṁ lokasannivāso.
analyzed: aham ca iva kho pana evam pabbajitaḥ samānaḥ kāma vitakkam vā vitakkeyya byāpāda vitakkam vā vitakkeyya vihisā vitakkam vā vitakkeyya mahā kho pana ayam loka sannivāsaḥ
translated: “If, while I am thus gone forth, I were to think thoughts of sensual desire, think thoughts of ill will, or think thoughts of doing harm, this great human population would be my downfall.

original: Mahantasmiṁ kho pana lokasannivāse santi samaṇabrāhmaṇā iddhimanto dibbacakkhukā paracittaviduno.🔽Te dūratopi passanti, āsannāpi na dissanti, cetasāpi cittaṁ pajānanti.
analyzed: mahantasmin kho pana loka sannivāse santi samaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ iddhimantaḥ dibba cakkhukā para citta vidunaḥ  te dūratas pi passanti āsannā api na dissanti cetasā api cittam pajānanti
translated: In this great human population there are ascetics and brahmins who have supernormal power, who are mind-readers.

original: Tepi maṁ evaṁ jāneyyuṁ:
analyzed: te api mam evam jāneyyu
translated: They might see me thus and say:🔽‘Look, sirs, at this gentleman, who has gone forth out of faith from the home life into homelessness. He is not purifying his mind from sensual desire, which is in opposition to it.

translated: ‘Look, sirs, at this young man who, with faith, has gone forth from the home life into homelessness, yet lives crowded with bad, unwholesome qualities.’

original: Tā dūratopi passanti, āsannāpi na dissanti, cetasāpi cittaṁ jānanti.

translated: They can see far into the distance, and they know what is in people’s minds.

original: Tāpi maṁ evaṁ jāneyyuṁ:
analyzed: tāḥ api mam evam jāneyyu
translated: They would know about me:

original: ‘passatha, bho, imaṁ kulaputtaṁ saddhā agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajito samāno vokiṇṇo viharati pāpakehi akusalehi dhammehī’ti.

translated: ‘Look, sirs, at this gentleman who has gone forth out of faith from the home life into homelessness. He is living mixed up with bad, unwholesome qualities.’

original: So iti paṭisañcikkhati:

original: ‘āraddhaṁ kho pana me vīriyaṁ bhavissati asallīnaṁ, upaṭṭhitā sati asammuṭṭhā, passaddho kāyo asāraddho, samāhitaṁ cittaṁ ekaggan’ti.
analyzed: āraddham kho pana me vīriyam bhavissati a sallīna upaṭṭhitā sati a sammuṭṭhā passaddhaḥ kāyaḥ a sāraddhaḥ samāhitam cittam ekaggan ti
translated: ‘My energy will be aroused and untiring, my mindfulness established and unconfused, my body calm and undisturbed, and my mind immersed in samādhi and unified.’

original: So lokaṁyeva adhipatiṁ karitvā akusalaṁ pajahati, kusalaṁ bhāveti, sāvajjaṁ pajahati, anavajjaṁ bhāveti, suddhaṁ attānaṁ pariharati.

translated: Relying on the world, he gives up what is unskillful and develops what is skillful, gives up what is blameworthy and develops what is blameless, and keeps himself pure.

original: Idaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, lokādhipateyyaṁ.

original: Idha, bhikkhave, bhikkhu araññagato vā rukkhamūlagato vā suññāgāragato vā iti paṭisañcikkhati:

original: ‘na kho panāhaṁ cīvarahetu agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajito.🔽Na piṇḍapātahetu, na senāsanahetu, na itibhavābhavahetu agārasmā anagāriyaṁ pabbajito.🔽Api ca khomhi otiṇṇo jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi, dukkhotiṇṇo dukkhapareto.
analyzed: na kho pana aham cīvara hetu agārasmai anagāriyam pabbajitaḥ  na piṇḍapāta hetu na senāsana hetu na iti bhava abhava hetu agārasma anagāriyam pabbajitaḥ  api ca khomhi otiṇṇaḥ jātiyā jarāya maraṇena sokehi paridevehi dukkhehi domanassehi upāyāsehi dukkha utiṇṇaḥ dukkha paretaḥ
translated: ‘I have not gone forth from the home life into homelessness for the sake of robes, almsfood, resting place, and medicinal requisites,🔽but rather I have gone forth from the home life into homelessness to untie the knot of the effluents, to end the cycle of suffering, to wear out the fetter, to destroy craving, to relinquish clinging, to sever the round, to exhaust the defilements.’

original: Appeva nāma imassa kevalassa dukkhakkhandhassa antakiriyā paññāyethāti.

translated: ‘I am beset by aging and death, afflicted by aging and death. When will I be free from this aging and death? When will a worthy one speak to me, a true person, about the subsiding of aging and death?

original: Svākkhāto bhagavatā dhammo sandiṭṭhiko akāliko ehipassiko opaneyyiko paccattaṁ veditabbo viññūhīti.
analyzed: su ākkhātaḥ bhagavatā dhammaḥ sandiṭṭhikaḥ akālikaḥ ehipassikaḥ opaneyyikaḥ paccattam veditabbaḥ viññūhi iti
translated: The Dhamma is well expounded by the Blessed One to be personally experienced by the wise.’

original: Santi kho pana me sabrahmacārī jānaṁ passaṁ viharanti.
analyzed: santi kho pana me sabrahmacārī jānam passam viharanti
translated: ‘There are fellow practitioners of mine who are wise, competent, and intelligent, who have good memory and retain what they have learned.

original: Ahañceva kho pana evaṁ svākkhāte dhammavinaye pabbajito samāno kusīto vihareyyaṁ pamatto, na metaṁ assa patirūpan’ti.

translated: If I, having gone forth thus in such a well-expounded Dhamma and Discipline, were to live lazying about, that would not be fitting for me.’

original: So iti paṭisañcikkhati:
analyzed: saḥ iti paṭisañcikkhati
translated: He considers thus:

original: ‘āraddhaṁ kho pana me vīriyaṁ bhavissati asallīnaṁ, upaṭṭhitā sati asammuṭṭhā, passaddho kāyo asāraddho, samāhitaṁ cittaṁ ekaggan’ti.
analyzed: āraddham kho pana me vīriyam bhavissati a sallīna upaṭṭhitā sati a sammuṭṭhā passaddhaḥ kāyaḥ a sāraddhaḥ samāhitam cittam ekaggan ti
translated: ‘My persistence will be aroused & not lax; my mindfulness established & not confused; my body calm & not agitated; my mind centered & unified.’

original: So dhammaṁyeva adhipatiṁ karitvā akusalaṁ pajahati, kusalaṁ bhāveti, sāvajjaṁ pajahati, anavajjaṁ bhāveti, suddhaṁ attānaṁ pariharati.
analyzed: saḥ dhammayā iva adhipatim karitvā akusalam pajahati kusalam bhāveti sāvajjam pajahati anavajjam bhāveti suddham attānam pariharati
translated: Making Dhamma his superior, he abandons what is unskillful & develops what is skillful, he abandons what is blameworthy & develops what is unblameworthy, he warms up his mind for the skillful.

original: Idaṁ vuccati, bhikkhave, dhammādhipateyyaṁ.
analyzed: idam vuccati bhikkhave dhamma ādhipateyya
translated: This is called superiority in terms of Dhamma.

original: “Tīhi, bhikkhave, aṅgehi samannāgato mahācoro sandhimpi chindati, nillopampi harati, ekāgārikampi karoti, paripanthepi tiṭṭhati.

original: Katamehi tīhi?
analyzed: katamehi tīhi
translated: What three?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, mahācoro visamanissito ca hoti, gahananissito ca hoti, balavanissito ca hoti.
analyzed: idha bhikkhave mahā coraḥ visama nissitaḥ ca hoti gahana nissitaḥ ca hoti balava nissitaḥ ca hoti
translated: Here, a great thief is supported by wilderness, is supported by the open country, and is supported by powerful people.

original: Kathañca, bhikkhave, mahācoro visamanissito hoti?🔽Idha, bhikkhave, mahācoro nadīviduggaṁ vā nissito hoti pabbatavisamaṁ vā.
analyzed: katham ca bhikkhave mahā coraḥ visama nissitaḥ hoti  idha bhikkhave mahā coraḥ nadī viduggam vā nissitaḥ hoti pabbata visamam vā
translated: And how is a great thief supported by wilderness?🔽Here, a great thief is supported by a wilderness that’s hard to traverse, hard to pass through.

original: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, mahācoro visamanissito hoti.
analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave mahā coraḥ visama nissitaḥ hoti
translated: This is how a great thief is supported by wilderness.

original: Kathañca, bhikkhave, mahācoro gahananissito hoti?
analyzed: katham ca bhikkhave mahā coraḥ gahana nissitaḥ hoti
translated: And how is a great thief supported by the open country?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, mahācoro tiṇagahanaṁ vā nissito hoti, rukkhagahanaṁ vā rodhaṁ vā mahāvanasaṇḍaṁ vā.
analyzed: idha bhikkhave mahā coraḥ tiṇa gahanam vā nissitaḥ hoti rukkha gahanam vā rodham vā mahā vana saṇḍam vā
translated: Here, a robber-chief has taken refuge in a thicket of reeds, in a forest, in a ravine, or in dense jungle.

original: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, mahācoro gahananissito hoti.
analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave mahā coraḥ gahana nissitaḥ hoti
translated: That’s how a robber-chief has taken refuge in a thicket.

original: Kathañca, bhikkhave, mahācoro balavanissito hoti?
analyzed: katham ca bhikkhave mahā coraḥ balava nissitaḥ hoti
translated: “And how does a robber-chief have powerful allies?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, mahācoro rājānaṁ vā rājamahāmattānaṁ vā nissito hoti.
analyzed: idha bhikkhave mahā coraḥ rājānam vā rāja mahāmattānam vā nissitaḥ hoti
translated: Here, a robber-chief has taken refuge in a king or a king’s minister.

original: Tassa evaṁ hoti:
analyzed: tassa evam hoti
translated: He thinks,

original: ‘sace maṁ koci kiñci vakkhati, ime me rājāno vā rājamahāmattā vā pariyodhāya atthaṁ bhaṇissantī’ti.
analyzed: sace mam koci kiñci vakkhati ime me rājānaḥ vā rāja mahāmattāḥ vā pariyodhāya attham bhaṇissanti iti
translated: ‘If anyone says anything to me, these kings or king’s ministers will protect me and defend me.’

original: Sace naṁ koci kiñci āha, tyāssa rājāno vā rājamahāmattā vā pariyodhāya atthaṁ bhaṇanti.
analyzed: sace nam koci kiñci āha rājānaḥ vā rāja mahāmattāḥ vā pariyodhāya attham bhaṇanti
translated: If anyone says anything to him, these kings or king’s ministers protect him and defend him.

original: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, mahācoro balavanissito hoti.
analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave mahā coraḥ balava nissitaḥ hoti
translated: That’s how a robber-chief has powerful allies.

original: Ime kho, bhikkhave, tīhi aṅgehi samannāgato mahācoro sandhimpi chindati, nillopampi harati, ekāgārikampi karoti, paripanthepi tiṭṭhati.
analyzed: ime kho bhikkhave tīhi aṅgehi samannāgataḥ mahā coraḥ sandhim pi chindati nillopam pi harati ekāgārikam pi karoti paripanthe pi tiṭṭhati
translated: “A robber-chief with these three qualities cuts the outer netting and escapes.

original: Evamevaṁ kho, bhikkhave, tīhi aṅgehi samannāgato pāpabhikkhu khataṁ upahataṁ attānaṁ pariharati, sāvajjo ca hoti sānuvajjo ca viññūnaṁ, bahuñca apuññaṁ pasavati.

translated: So too, bhikkhus, a bad bhikkhu who possesses three qualities destroys himself, is blamed and criticized by others, and generates much demerit.

original: Katamehi tīhi?
analyzed: katamehi tīhi
translated: What three?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, pāpabhikkhu visamanissito ca hoti gahananissito ca balavanissito ca.

translated: Here, bhikkhus, a bad bhikkhu is supported by families in a way that is improper and unsuitable.

original: Idha, bhikkhave, pāpabhikkhu visamena kāyakammena samannāgato hoti, visamena vacīkammena samannāgato hoti, visamena manokammena samannāgato hoti.🔽Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, pāpabhikkhu visamanissito hoti.

translated: It is in this way that a bad bhikkhu is supported by families in a way that is improper and unsuitable.

original: Kathañca, bhikkhave, pāpabhikkhu gahananissito hoti?
analyzed: katham ca bhikkhave pāpa bhikkhu gahana nissitaḥ hoti
translated: And how, bhikkhus, is a bad bhikkhu supported by families in a way that is excessive?

translated: Here, bhikkhus, a bad bhikkhu is of wrong view, of wrong intention, of wrong speech, of wrong action, of wrong livelihood, of wrong effort, of wrong mindfulness, of wrong concentration, of wrong knowledge, and of wrong deliverance.

original: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, pāpabhikkhu gahananissito hoti.
analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave pāpa bhikkhu gahana nissitaḥ hoti
translated: That’s how a bad monk is supported by the wilderness.

original: Kathañca, bhikkhave, pāpabhikkhu balavanissito hoti?
analyzed: katham ca bhikkhave pāpa bhikkhu balava nissitaḥ hoti
translated: “And how is a bad monk supported by the powerful?

original: Idha, bhikkhave, pāpabhikkhu rājānaṁ vā rājamahāmattānaṁ vā nissito hoti.
analyzed: idha bhikkhave pāpa bhikkhu rājānam vā rāja mahāmattānam vā nissitaḥ hoti
translated: It’s when a bad monk is supported by kings or royal ministers.

original: Tassa evaṁ hoti:

translated: He thinks,

original: ‘sace maṁ koci kiñci vakkhati, ime me rājāno vā rājamahāmattā vā pariyodhāya atthaṁ bhaṇissantī’ti.
analyzed: sace mam koci kiñci vakkhati ime me rājānaḥ vā rāja mahāmattāḥ vā pariyodhāya attham bhaṇissanti iti
translated: ‘If anyone says anything to me, these kings or royal ministers will defend me.’

original: Sace naṁ koci kiñci āha, tyāssa rājāno vā rājamahāmattā vā pariyodhāya atthaṁ bhaṇanti.
analyzed: sace nam koci kiñci āha rājānaḥ vā rāja mahāmattāḥ vā pariyodhāya attham bhaṇanti
translated: And if anyone says anything to him, those kings or royal ministers do defend him.

original: Evaṁ kho, bhikkhave, pāpabhikkhu balavanissito hoti.
analyzed: evam kho bhikkhave pāpa bhikkhu balava nissitaḥ hoti
translated: That’s how a bad monk is supported by the powerful.

translated: A bad monk who has these three qualities preserves his own welfare and happiness in both this life and the next. He is faulted and criticized by sensible people, and he makes much bad karma.”

analyzed: atha kho dve brāhmaṇāḥ jiṇṇāḥ vuddhāḥ mahallakāḥ addha gatāḥ vayaḥ anuppattāḥ vīsa vassasatikāḥ jātiyā yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkamisu upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhim sammodisu  sammodanīyam katham sāraṇīyam vītisāretvā ekamantam nisīdisu ekamantam nisinnāḥ kho te brāhmaṇāḥ bhagavantam etat avocuḥ
translated: Then two brahmins, old, aged, burdened with years, advanced in life, come to the last stage, a hundred and twenty years old, went to the Buddha and exchanged greetings with him.

original: “mayamassu, bho gotama, brāhmaṇā jiṇṇā vuddhā mahallakā addhagatā vayoanuppattā vīsavassasatikā jātiyā;

translated: When this courteous and amiable talk was finished, they sat down to one side and said to him, “Master Gotama, we are brahmins, old, aged, burdened with years, advanced in life, come to the last stage, a hundred and twenty years old.

original: te camhā akatakalyāṇā akatakusalā akatabhīruttāṇā.

translated: But you have not done what is good, wholesome, and skillful, nor have you made yourselves a shelter from anguish.🔽This world is swept away by aging, illness, and death.

analyzed: evam upanīyamāne khalu brāhmaṇāḥ loke jarāya byādhinā maraṇena yaḥ idha kāyena sayamaḥ

translated: one should make merit, which brings happiness.

original: Yodha kāyena saṁyamo,
analyzed: yodha kāyena sayamo
translated: If one is restrained by body,

analyzed: vācāya uda cetasā
translated: by speech, and by mind,

original: Taṁ tassa petassa sukhāya hoti,
analyzed: tam tassa petassa sukhāya hoti
translated: that is for the happiness of the deceased,

original: Yaṁ jīvamāno pakaroti puññan”ti.
analyzed: yam jīvamānaḥ pakaroti

original: Atha kho aññataro brāhmaṇo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṁ sammodi …pe… ekamantaṁ nisinno kho so brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: atha kho aññataraḥ brāhmaṇaḥ yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhim sammodi pe ekamantam nisinnaḥ kho saḥ brāhmaṇaḥ bhagavantam etat avoca
translated: Then a certain brahmin went up to the Buddha, and after exchanging greetings and compliments, he sat down to one side and said to him:

original: “‘sandiṭṭhiko dhammo sandiṭṭhiko dhammo’ti, bho gotama, vuccati.
analyzed: sandiṭṭhikaḥ dhammo sandiṭṭhikaḥ dhammo ti bho gotama vuccati
translated: “‘A teaching visible in this very life, a teaching immediate, inviting one to come and see, onward-leading, to be personally experienced by the wise.’ So it is said, Master Gotama.

original: Kittāvatā nu kho, bho gotama, sandiṭṭhiko dhammo hoti akāliko ehipassiko opaneyyiko paccattaṁ veditabbo viññūhī”ti?🔽“Ratto kho, brāhmaṇa, rāgena abhibhūto pariyādinnacitto attabyābādhāyapi ceteti, parabyābādhāyapi ceteti, ubhayabyābādhāyapi ceteti, cetasikampi dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti.
analyzed: kittāvatā nu kho bho gotama sandiṭṭhikaḥ dhammaḥ hoti akālikaḥ ehipassikaḥ opaneyyikaḥ paccattam veditabbaḥ viññūhi iti  rattaḥ kho brāhmaṇa rāgena abhibhūtaḥ pariyādinna cittaḥ atta byābādhāya api cetā iti para byābādhāya api cetā iti ubhaya byābādhāya api cetā iti cetasikam pi dukkham domanassam paṭisavedeti
translated: In what way is the teaching visible in this very life, immediate, inviting one to come and see, onward-leading, to be personally experienced by the wise?”🔽“Brahmin, one full of passion, overcome by passion, with mind obsessed by it, intends for his own affliction, for the affliction of others, and for the affliction of both, and he experiences mental suffering and dejection.

original: Rāge pahīne nevattabyābādhāyapi ceteti, na parabyābādhāyapi ceteti, na ubhayabyābādhāyapi ceteti, na cetasikaṁ dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti.
analyzed: rāge pahīne na ivatta byābādhāya api ceteti na para byābādhāya api ceteti na ubhaya byābādhāya api ceteti na cetasikam dukkham domanassam paṭisavedeti
translated: When passion is abandoned, he does not intend for his own affliction, for the affliction of others, or for the affliction of both, and he does not experience mental suffering and dejection.

original: Ratto kho …pe… kāyena duccaritaṁ carati, vācāya duccaritaṁ carati, manasā duccaritaṁ carati.
analyzed: kāyena duccaritam carati vācāya duccaritam carati manasā duccaritam carati
translated: One who is greedy …🔽One who is greedy …🔽One who is greedy …

original: Rāge pahīne neva kāyena duccaritaṁ carati, na vācāya duccaritaṁ carati, na manasā duccaritaṁ carati.🔽Ratto kho …pe… attatthampi yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāti, paratthampi yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāti, ubhayatthampi yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāti.🔽Rāge pahīne attatthampi yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, paratthampi yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ubhayatthampi yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti.🔽Evampi kho, brāhmaṇa, sandiṭṭhiko dhammo hoti …pe….
analyzed: rāge pahīne na iva kāyena duccaritam carati na vācāya duccaritam carati na manasā duccaritam carati  rattaḥ kho pe attattham pi yathābhūtam na pajānāti parattham pi yathābhūtam na pajānāti ubhayattham pi yathābhūtam na pajānāti  rāge pahīne attattham pi yathābhūtam pajānāti parattham pi yathābhūtam pajānāti ubhayattham pi yathābhūtam pajānāti  evam pi kho brāhmaṇa sandiṭṭhikaḥ dhammaḥ hoti pe
translated: One who is greedy …🔽“So it is, brahmin, that the Dhamma is visible here and now, immediately effective, inviting inspection, onward-leading, and to be experienced by the wise for themselves.”

original: Duṭṭho kho, brāhmaṇa, dosena abhibhūto pariyādinnacitto attabyābādhāyapi ceteti, parabyābādhāyapi ceteti, ubhayabyābādhāyapi ceteti, cetasikampi dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti.
analyzed: duṭṭhaḥ kho brāhmaṇa dosena abhibhūtaḥ pariyādinna cittaḥ atta byābādhāya api cetā iti para byābādhāya api cetā iti ubhaya byābādhāya api cetā iti cetasikam pi dukkham domanassam paṭisavedeti
translated: “Brahmin, one who is hateful …

original: Dose pahīne nevattabyābādhāyapi ceteti, na parabyābādhāyapi ceteti, na ubhayabyābādhāyapi ceteti, na cetasikampi dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti.
analyzed: dose pahīne na ivatta byābādhāya api ceteti na para byābādhāya api ceteti na ubhaya byābādhāya api ceteti na cetasikam pi dukkham domanassam paṭisavedeti
translated: When greed is abandoned, one does not intend for one’s own affliction, for the affliction of others, or for the affliction of both, and one does not experience mental suffering and dejection.

original: Evampi kho, brāhmaṇa, sandiṭṭhiko dhammo hoti …pe….
analyzed: evam pi kho brāhmaṇa sandiṭṭhikaḥ dhammaḥ hoti pe
translated: In this way, brahmin, the Dhamma is visible here and now, immediately effective, inviting inspection, onward leading, to be experienced by the wise for themselves.”

original: Mūḷho kho, brāhmaṇa, mohena abhibhūto pariyādinnacitto attabyābādhāyapi ceteti, parabyābādhāyapi ceteti, ubhayabyābādhāyapi ceteti, cetasikampi dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti.
analyzed: mūḷhaḥ kho brāhmaṇa mohena abhibhūtaḥ pariyādinna cittaḥ atta byābādhāya api cetā iti para byābādhāya api cetā iti ubhaya byābādhāya api cetā iti cetasikam pi dukkham domanassam paṭisavedeti
translated: “When a fool is overcome and oppressed by delusion, his mind is not rightly concentrated for the destruction of the taints.

original: Mohe pahīne nevattabyābādhāyapi ceteti, na parabyābādhāyapi ceteti, na ubhayabyābādhāyapi ceteti, na cetasikaṁ dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti.
analyzed: mohe pahīne na ivatta byābādhāya api ceteti na para byābādhāya api ceteti na ubhaya byābādhāya api ceteti na cetasikam dukkham domanassam paṭisavedeti
translated: When delusion is abandoned, one does not intend for one’s own affliction, for the affliction of others, or for the affliction of both, and one does not experience mental suffering and dejection.

original: Evaṁ kho, brāhmaṇa, sandiṭṭhiko dhammo hoti akāliko ehipassiko opaneyyiko paccattaṁ veditabbo viññūhī”ti.
analyzed: evam kho brāhmaṇa sandiṭṭhikaḥ dhammaḥ hoti akālikaḥ ehipassikaḥ opaneyyikaḥ paccattam veditabbaḥ viññūhi iti
translated: In this way, brahmin, the Dhamma is visible here and now, immediately effective, inviting inspection, onward leading, to be experienced by the wise for themselves.”

original: “Abhikkantaṁ, bho gotama, abhikkantaṁ, bho gotama.
analyzed: abhikkanta bho gotama abhikkanta bho gotama
translated: “Excellent, Master Gotama! Excellent, Master Gotama!

original: Seyyathāpi, bho gotama, nikkujjitaṁ vā ukkujjeyya, paṭicchannaṁ vā vivareyya, mūḷhassa
analyzed: seyyathā api bho gotama nikkujjitam vā ukkujjeyya paṭicchannam vā vivareyya mūḷhassa
translated: Just as one might set upright what has been overturned,

original: vā maggaṁ ācikkheyya, andhakāre vā telapajjotaṁ dhāreyya: ‘cakkhumanto rūpāni dakkhantī’ti;
analyzed: vā maggam ācikkheyya andhakāre vā tela pajjotam dhāreyya cakkhumantaḥ rūpāni dakkhanti iti
translated: or reveal what has been hidden, or show the way to one who is lost, or bring a lamp into the darkness so that one with eyes might see what is there—

analyzed: evam evam bhotā gotamena aneka pariyāyena dhammo pakāsito
translated: just so has the Lord Gotama made the Dhamma clear in many ways.

translated: I go to the Lord Gotama for refuge and to the Dhamma and to the Sangha of bhikkhus.

original: Upāsakaṁ maṁ bhavaṁ gotamo dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṁ saraṇaṁ gatan”ti.🔽Tatiyaṁ.
analyzed: upāsakam mam bhavam gotamaḥ dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetam saraṇam gatanti  tatiya
translated: May the Lord Gotama remember me as a lay-follower who has gone to him for refuge, from this day forward, for life.”

analyzed: kittāvatā nu kho bho gotama sandiṭṭhikaḥ dhammaḥ hoti akālikaḥ ehipassikaḥ opaneyyikaḥ paccattam veditabbaḥ viññūhi iti
translated: In what way, Master Gotama, is the Dhamma expounded by him directly visible, immediate, inviting one to come and see, applicable, to be personally experienced by the wise?”

original: “Ratto kho, brāhmaṇa, rāgena abhibhūto pariyādinnacitto attabyābādhāyapi ceteti, parabyābādhāyapi ceteti, ubhayabyābādhāyapi ceteti, cetasikampi dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti.🔽Rāge pahīne nevattabyābādhāyapi ceteti, na parabyābādhāyapi ceteti, na ubhayabyābādhāyapi ceteti, na cetasikampi dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti.🔽Ratto kho, brāhmaṇa, rāgena abhibhūto pariyādinnacitto kāyena duccaritaṁ carati, vācāya duccaritaṁ carati, manasā duccaritaṁ carati.
analyzed: rattaḥ kho brāhmaṇa rāgena abhibhūtaḥ pariyādinna cittaḥ atta byābādhāya api cetā iti para byābādhāya api cetā iti ubhaya byābādhāya api cetā iti cetasikam pi dukkham domanassam paṭisavedeti  rāge pahīne na ivatta byābādhāya api cetā iti na para byābādhāya api cetā iti na ubhaya byābādhāya api cetā iti na cetasikam pi dukkham domanassam paṭisavedeti  rattaḥ kho brāhmaṇa rāgena abhibhūtaḥ pariyādinna cittaḥ kāyena duccaritam carati vācāya duccaritam carati manasā duccaritam carati
translated: “Brahmin, one full of passion, overwhelmed and with mind obsessed by passion, intends for his own affliction, for the affliction of others, and for the affliction of both, and he experiences mental suffering and dejection.

original: Rāge pahīne neva kāyena duccaritaṁ carati, na vācāya duccaritaṁ carati, na manasā duccaritaṁ carati.
analyzed: rāge pahīne na iva kāyena duccaritam carati na vācāya duccaritam carati na manasā duccaritam carati
translated: When passion is abandoned, he does not intend for his own affliction, for the affliction of others, or for the affliction of both, and he does not experience mental suffering and dejection.🔽“One full of passion, overwhelmed and with mind obsessed by passion, conducts himself in a way that causes his own affliction, causes the affliction of others, and causes the affliction of both, and he does not know the escape in regard to the arising of states of defilement that have not arisen and the abandoning of states of defilement that have arisen.🔽When passion is abandoned, he conducts himself in a way that does not cause his own affliction, does not cause the affliction of others, and does not cause the affliction of both, and he knows the escape in regard to the arising of states of defilement that have not arisen and the abandoning of states of defilement that have arisen.

original: Ratto kho, brāhmaṇa, rāgena abhibhūto pariyādinnacitto attatthampi yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāti, paratthampi yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāti, ubhayatthampi yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāti.
analyzed: rattaḥ kho brāhmaṇa rāgena abhibhūtaḥ pariyādinna cittaḥ atta attham pi yathābhūtam na pajānāti parattham pi yathābhūtam na pajānāti ubhayattham pi yathābhūtam na pajānāti
translated: One who is greedy, overcome by greed, his mind controlled by it, does not understand his own good, the good of others, or the good of both, and in the long run he suffers great harm and sorrow.

original: Rāge pahīne attatthampi yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, paratthampi yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ubhayatthampi yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti.
analyzed: rāge pahīne attattham pi yathābhūtam pajānāti parattham pi yathābhūtam pajānāti ubhayattham pi yathābhūtam pajānāti
translated: But when greed is abandoned, he understands his own good, the good of others, and the good of both, and in the long run he feels great pleasure and happiness.

original: Evampi kho, brāhmaṇa, sandiṭṭhiko dhammo hoti …pe….
analyzed: evam pi kho brāhmaṇa sandiṭṭhikaḥ dhammaḥ hoti pe
translated: In this way, brahmin, the Dhamma is visible here and now, immediately effective, inviting one to come and see, applicable, to be personally experienced by the wise.”

original: Duṭṭho kho, brāhmaṇa, dosena …pe…
analyzed: duṭṭhaḥ kho brāhmaṇa dosena pe
translated: “One who is hateful, overcome by hatred, his mind controlled by it, does not understand his own good, the good of others, or the good of both, and in the long run he suffers great harm and sorrow.🔽But when hatred is abandoned, he understands his own good, the good of others, and the good of both, and in the long run he feels great pleasure and happiness.

original: mūḷho kho, brāhmaṇa, mohena abhibhūto pariyādinnacitto attabyābādhāyapi ceteti, parabyābādhāyapi ceteti, ubhayabyābādhāyapi ceteti, cetasikampi dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti.
analyzed: mūḷhaḥ kho brāhmaṇa mohena abhibhūtaḥ pariyādinna cittaḥ atta byābādhāya api cetā iti para byābādhāya api cetā iti ubhaya byābādhāya api cetā iti cetasikam pi dukkham domanassam paṭisavedeti
translated: “One who is deluded, overcome by delusion, his mind controlled by it, intends for his own affliction, for the affliction of others, and for the affliction of both, and he experiences mental suffering and dejection.

original: Mohe pahīne nevattabyābādhāyapi ceteti, na parabyābādhāyapi ceteti, na ubhayabyābādhāyapi ceteti, na cetasikaṁ dukkhaṁ domanassaṁ paṭisaṁvedeti.
analyzed: mohe pahīne na ivatta byābādhāya api ceteti na para byābādhāya api ceteti na ubhaya byābādhāya api ceteti na cetasikam dukkham domanassam paṭisavedeti
translated: But when delusion is abandoned, he does not intend for his own affliction, for the affliction of others, or for the affliction of both, and he does not experience mental suffering and dejection.

original: Mūḷho kho, brāhmaṇa, mohena abhibhūto pariyādinnacitto, kāyena duccaritaṁ carati, vācāya duccaritaṁ carati, manasā duccaritaṁ carati.
analyzed: mūḍhaḥ khalu brāhmaṇa mohena abhibhūtaḥ pariyādinna cittaḥ kāyena duccaritam carati vācāya duccaritam carati manasā duccaritam carati
translated: When a person is deluded, overcome by delusion, his mind is gripped by delusion. He does what is unskillful, does what is not worthy of a noble one, and does what is not proper for a recluse.

original: Mohe pahīne neva kāyena duccaritaṁ carati, na vācāya duccaritaṁ carati, na manasā duccaritaṁ carati.
analyzed: mohe pahīne na iva kāyena duccaritam carati na vācāya duccaritam carati na manasā duccaritam carati
translated: When delusion is abandoned, he does not do what is unskillful, does not do what is not worthy of a noble one, and does not do what is not proper for a recluse.

original: Mūḷho kho, brāhmaṇa, mohena abhibhūto pariyādinnacitto attatthampi yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāti, paratthampi yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāti, ubhayatthampi yathābhūtaṁ nappajānāti.
analyzed: mūḷhaḥ kho brāhmaṇa mohena abhibhūtaḥ pariyādinna cittaḥ atta attham pi yathābhūtam na pajānāti parattham pi yathābhūtam na pajānāti ubhayattham pi yathābhūtam na pajānāti
translated: When a person is deluded, overcome by delusion, he does not understand his own good, he does not understand the good of others, and he does not understand the good of both.

original: Mohe pahīne attatthampi yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, paratthampi yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ubhayatthampi yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti.
analyzed: mohe pahīne attattham pi yathābhūtam pajānāti parattham pi yathābhūtam pajānāti ubhayattham pi yathābhūtam pajānāti
translated: When delusion is abandoned, he understands his own good, he understands the good of others, and he understands the good of both.

original: Evaṁ kho, brāhmaṇa, sandiṭṭhiko dhammo hoti akāliko ehipassiko opaneyyiko paccattaṁ veditabbo viññūhī”ti.
analyzed: evam kho brāhmaṇa sandiṭṭhikaḥ dhammaḥ hoti akālikaḥ ehipassikaḥ opaneyyikaḥ paccattam veditabbaḥ viññūhi iti
translated: It is in such a way that one can cite a visible example of a Dhamma that is directly visible, immediate, inviting one to come and see, applicable, to be personally experienced by the wise.”

original: “Abhikkantaṁ, bho gotama …pe…
analyzed: abhikkanta bho gotama pe
translated: “Magnificent, Master Gotama! Magnificent! …🔽… And so, Master Gotama, we now go for refuge to Master Gotama, to the Dhamma, and to the Sangha of bhikkhus.

translated: From this day forth, may Master Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone to him for refuge for life.”🔽The fourth section on “one who has one quality” is finished.

analyzed: paññāyati gāmā api a gāmāḥ honti nigamā api a nigamāḥ honti nagarā api a nagarāḥ honti janapadā api a janapadāḥ honti iti

translated: They take up sharp knives and kill each other, and so many die.

translated: This is the cause and reason why the human population is now decreasing,🔽and why villages, towns, and capital cities are becoming deserted.”

translated: And so the spirits and demons let loose their plagues, and many people die.

translated: “Those who say, ‘Master Gotama says this,’

original: “mayhameva dānaṁ dātabbaṁ, nāññesaṁ dānaṁ dātabbaṁ.🔽Mayhameva sāvakānaṁ dānaṁ dātabbaṁ, nāññesaṁ sāvakānaṁ dānaṁ dātabbaṁ.

translated: Only what is given to me has great fruit, not what is given to others.

original: Yo kho, vaccha, paraṁ dānaṁ dadantaṁ vāreti so imesaṁ tiṇṇaṁ antarāyakaro hoti, tiṇṇaṁ pāripanthiko.🔽Ahaṁ kho pana, vaccha, evaṁ vadāmi:
analyzed: yaḥ kho vaccha param dānam dadantam vāreti saḥ imesam tiṇṇam antarāya karaḥ hoti tiṇṇam pāripanthiko  aham kho pana vacche evam vadāmi

original: Api cāhaṁ, vaccha, sīlavato dinnaṁ mahapphalaṁ vadāmi, no tathā dussīlassa, so ca hoti pañcaṅgavippahīno pañcaṅgasamannāgato.

original: “Yathā kathaṁ pana, brāhmaṇa, brāhmaṇā brāhmaṇaṁ tevijjaṁ paññāpentī”ti?🔽“Idha, bho gotama, brāhmaṇo ubhato sujāto hoti mātito ca pitito ca, saṁsuddhagahaṇiko
analyzed: yathā katham pana brāhmaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ brāhmaṇam tevijjam paññāpenti iti  idha bho gotama brāhmaṇaḥ ubhatas su jātaḥ hoti mātitaḥ ca pititaḥ ca sa suddha gahaṇikaḥ
translated: “But, brahmin, how do the brahmins describe a brahmin who is learned in the Three Vedas?”🔽“Sir, a brahmin is well-born on both his mother’s and father’s side, of pure descent to the seventh paternal generation, unassailable and impeccable with respect to birth.

original: yāva sattamā pitāmahayugā, akkhitto anupakkuṭṭho jātivādena, ajjhāyako, mantadharo,🔽tiṇṇaṁ vedānaṁ pāragū sanighaṇḍukeṭubhānaṁ sākkharappabhedānaṁ itihāsapañcamānaṁ,
analyzed: yāva sattamā pitāmaha yugā akkhittaḥ an upakkuṭṭhaḥ jāti vādena ajjhāyakaḥ manta dharo  tiṇṇam vedānam pāragū sa nighaṇḍu keṭubhānam sa akkhara ppabhedānam itihāsa pañcamānam
translated: He has memorized the hymns and mastered the sacred chants.🔽He is well-versed in the range of the Three Vedas, with their vocabularies, liturgy, phonology, and etymologies, and the histories as a fifth.

original: padako, veyyākaraṇo, lokāyatamahāpurisalakkhaṇesu anavayoti.
analyzed: padakaḥ veyyākaraṇaḥ lokāyata mahāpurisa lakkhaṇesu
translated: He knows philology and grammar, and is well versed in cosmology and the marks of a great man.”

original: Evaṁ kho, bho gotama, brāhmaṇā brāhmaṇaṁ tevijjaṁ paññāpentī”ti.

translated: That is how the brahmins describe a brahmin who is accomplished in the three Vedas.”🔽“Brahmins describe a brahmin who is accomplished in the three Vedas in one way,

original: “Aññathā kho, brāhmaṇa, brāhmaṇā brāhmaṇaṁ tevijjaṁ paññāpenti, aññathā ca pana ariyassa vinaye tevijjo hotī”ti.
analyzed: aññathā kho brāhmaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ brāhmaṇam tevijjam paññāpenti aññathā ca pana ariyassa vinaye tevijjaḥ hoti iti
translated: but in the Noble One’s discipline one who is accomplished in the three knowledges is described in another way.”

original: “Yathā kathaṁ pana, bho gotama, ariyassa vinaye tevijjo hoti?
analyzed: yathā katham pana bho gotama ariyassa vinaye tevijjaḥ hoti
translated: “But how is one who is accomplished in the three knowledges described in the Noble One’s discipline?

original: Sādhu me bhavaṁ gotamo tathā dhammaṁ desetu yathā ariyassa vinaye tevijjo hotī”ti.
analyzed: sādhu me bhavam gotamaḥ tathā dhammam desetu yathā ariyassa vinaye tevijjaḥ hoti iti
translated: It would be good if Master Gotama were to teach me the Dhamma so that I might know how one who is accomplished in the three knowledges is described in the Noble One’s discipline.”

original: “Tena hi, brāhmaṇa, suṇāhi, sādhukaṁ manasi karohi; bhāsissāmī”ti.
analyzed: tena hi brāhmaṇa suṇāhi sādhukam manasi karohi bhāsissāmi iti
translated: “Then listen and attend closely to what I shall say.”

original: “Evaṁ, bho”ti kho tikaṇṇo brāhmaṇo bhagavato paccassosi.
analyzed: eva bhoti kho tikaṇṇaḥ brāhmaṇaḥ bhagavataḥ paccassosi
translated: “Yes, sir,” Tikaṇṇa the brahmin replied.

original: Bhagavā etadavoca:
analyzed: bhagavān etat avoca
translated: The Blessed One said this:

original: “Idha, brāhmaṇa, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi savitakkaṁ savicāraṁ vivekajaṁ pītisukhaṁ paṭhamaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: idha brāhmaṇa bhikkhu vivicca iva kāmehi vivicca akusalehi dhammehi sa vitakkam sa vicāram viveka jam pīti sukham paṭhamam jhānam upasampajja viharati
translated: “Here, brahmin, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unwholesome states, a bhikkhu enters upon and abides in the first jhana, which is accompanied by applied and sustained thought, with rapture and pleasure born of seclusion.

original: Vitakkavicārānaṁ vūpasamā ajjhattaṁ sampasādanaṁ cetaso ekodibhāvaṁ avitakkaṁ avicāraṁ samādhijaṁ pītisukhaṁ dutiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.🔽Pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca viharati sato ca sampajāno, sukhañca kāyena paṭisaṁvedeti
analyzed: vitakka vicārānam vūpasamāḥ ajjhattam sampasādanam cetasaḥ eka udi bhāvam a vitakkam a vicāram samādhi jam pīti sukham dutiyam jhānam upasampajja viharati  pītiyā ca virāgā upekkhako ca viharati sataḥ ca sampajāno sukham ca kāyena paṭisavedeti
translated: With the stilling of applied and sustained thought, he enters upon and abides in the second jhana, which has internal confidence and singleness of mind without applied thought, without sustained thought, with happiness and bliss born of concentration.

original: yaṁ taṁ ariyā ācikkhanti: ‘upekkhako satimā sukhavihārī’ti tatiyaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: yam tam ariyāḥ ācikkhanti upekkhakaḥ satimā sukha vihārī iti tatiyam jhānam upasampajja viharati
translated: With the fading away as well of happiness, he abides in equanimity, and mindful and fully aware, still feeling bliss, he enters upon and abides in the third jhana, on account of which noble ones announce: ‘He has a pleasant abiding who has equanimity and is mindful.’

original: Sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā, pubbeva somanassadomanassānaṁ atthaṅgamā adukkhamasukhaṁ upekkhāsatipārisuddhiṁ catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: sukhassa ca pahānā dukkhassa ca pahānā pubbā iva somanassa domanassānam atthaṅgamā adukkham asukham upekkhā sati pārisuddhim catuttham jhānam upasampajja viharati
translated: With the abandoning of pleasure and pain, and with the previous disappearance of joy and grief, he enters upon and abides in the fourth jhana, which has neither-pain-nor-pleasure and purity of mindfulness due to equanimity.

original: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇāya cittaṁ abhininnāmeti.
analyzed: saḥ evam samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigata upakkilese mudu bhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñja ppatte pubbenivāsa anussati ñāṇāya cittam abhininnāmeti
translated: “When his concentrated mind is thus purified, bright, unblemished, rid of imperfection, malleable, wieldy, steady, and attained to imperturbability, he directs it to knowledge of the recollection of past lives.

original: So anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati, seyyathidaṁ—ekampi jātiṁ dvepi jātiyo tissopi🔽jātiyo catassopi jātiyo pañcapi jātiyo dasapi jātiyo vīsampi jātiyo tiṁsampi jātiyo🔽cattārīsampi jātiyo paññāsampi jātiyo jātisatampi jātisahassampi jātisatasahassampi,
analyzed: so aneka vihitam pubbenivāsam anussarati seyyathida ekam pi jātim dve pi jātiyaḥ tissaḥ api  jātiyo catasso pi jātiyaḥ pañca api jātiyaḥ dasa api jātiyaḥ vīsampi jātiyaḥ tisampi jātiyaḥ  cattārīsam pi jātiyaḥ paññāsam pi jātiyaḥ jāti satam pi jāti sahassam pi jāti sata sahassam pi
translated: He remembers various past lives, i.e. one birth, two, three, four, five, ten, twenty, thirty, forty, fifty,

original: anekepi saṁvaṭṭakappe anekepi vivaṭṭakappe anekepi saṁvaṭṭavivaṭṭakappe: ‘amutrāsiṁ
analyzed: aneke api savaṭṭa kappe aneke api vivaṭṭa kappe aneke api savaṭṭa vivaṭṭa kappe amutra asi
translated: a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand, many eons of cosmic contraction, many eons of cosmic expansion, many eons of cosmic contraction and expansion: ‘There I had such a name, belonged to such a clan, had such an appearance.

original: evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī evamāyupariyanto,🔽so tato cuto amutra udapādiṁ. Tatrāpāsiṁ evaṁnāmo evaṅgotto evaṁvaṇṇo evamāhāro evaṁsukhadukkhappaṭisaṁvedī
analyzed: eva nāmaḥ evaṃgotto eva vaṇṇo evam āhāro eva sukha dukkha paṭisavedī evam āyu pariyanto  saḥ tatas cutaḥ amutra udapādi tatra apāsim eva nāmaḥ evaṃgottaḥ eva vaṇṇo evam āhāraḥ eva sukha dukkha ppaṭisavedī
translated: Such was my food, such my sensitivity to pleasure and pain, such the end of my life.🔽Passing away from that state, I re-arose there. There too I had such a name, belonged to such a clan, had such an appearance.

original: evamāyupariyanto, so tato cuto idhūpapanno’ti. Iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ🔽pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati.
analyzed: evam āyu pariyantaḥ saḥ tatas cutaḥ idhu upapanno ti iti sa ākāram sa uddesam aneka vihita  pubbenivāsam anussarati
translated: Such was my food, such my sensitivity to pleasure and pain, such the end of my life. Passing away from that state, I re-arose here.’ Thus with its characteristics and particulars, he remembers various past lives.

original: Ayamassa paṭhamā vijjā adhigatā hoti;
analyzed: ayam assa paṭhamā vijjā adhigatā hoti
translated: This is the first knowledge he has attained.

original: avijjā vihatā, vijjā uppannā; tamo vihato, āloko uppanno yathā taṁ appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato.
analyzed: avijjā vihatā vijjā uppannā tamaḥ vihataḥ ālokaḥ uppannaḥ yathā tam appamattassa ātāpinaḥ pahitattassa viharato
translated: ignorance was destroyed; knowledge arose; darkness was destroyed; light arose — as happens in one who dwells diligent, ardent, and resolute.

original: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte sattānaṁ cutūpapātañāṇāya cittaṁ abhininnāmeti.🔽So dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne🔽hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe, sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānāti: ‘ime
analyzed: saḥ evam samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigata upakkilese mudu bhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñja ppatte sattānam cutūpapāta ñāṇāya cittam abhininnāmeti  so dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkanta mānusakena satte passati cavamāne upapajjamāne  hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānāti ime
translated: When his mind was thus concentrated, purified, bright, unblemished, rid of defilement, pliant, malleable, steady, and attained to imperturbability, he directed it to knowledge of the passing away and reappearance of beings.🔽With the divine eye, which is purified and surpasses the human, he saw beings passing away and reappearing, inferior and superior, fair and ugly, fortunate and unfortunate. He understood how beings pass on according to their actions thus:

original: vata bhonto sattā kāyaduccaritena samannāgatā …pe… manoduccaritena samannāgatā ariyānaṁ
analyzed: vata bhonto sattā kāya duccaritena samannāgatā pe manaḥ duccaritena samannāgatā
translated: ‘These worthy beings who are possessed of wrong view, wrong resolve, wrong speech, wrong action, wrong livelihood, wrong effort, wrong mindfulness, wrong concentration, wrong knowledge, and wrong liberation —

original: upavādakā micchādiṭṭhikā micchādiṭṭhikammasamādānā, te kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā
analyzed: upavādakā micchādiṭṭhikā micchādiṭṭhi kamma samādānā te kāyassa bhedā param maraṇā
translated: at the breaking up of the body after death have reappeared in a plane of deprivation, a bad destination, a lower realm, hell.

original: apāyaṁ duggatiṁ vinipātaṁ nirayaṁ upapannā. Ime vā pana bhonto sattā kāyasucaritena
analyzed: apāyam duggatim vinipātam nirayam upapannāḥ ime vā pana bhonto sattā kāya su caritena
translated: But these worthy beings who are possessed of right view, right resolve, right speech, right action, right livelihood, right effort, right mindfulness, right concentration, right knowledge, and right liberation —

original: samannāgatā, vacīsucaritena samannāgatā, manosucaritena samannāgatā ariyānaṁ anupavādakā🔽sammādiṭṭhikā sammādiṭṭhikammasamādānā, te kāyassa bhedā paraṁ maraṇā sugatiṁ saggaṁ🔽lokaṁ upapannā’ti. Iti dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena satte passati
analyzed: samannāgatāḥ vacī su caritena samannāgatāḥ manaḥ su caritena samannāgatāḥ ariyānam an upavādakā  sammādiṭṭhikā sammādiṭṭhi kamma samādānā te kāyassa bhedā param maraṇā sugatim sagga  lokam upapannāti iti dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkanta mānusakena satte passati
translated: They are endowed with verbal good conduct, endowed with mental good conduct, and they do not revile the noble ones.🔽They have right view, and the actions born of right view, and on the dissolution of the body, after death, they have reappeared in a good destination, in a heavenly world.’ Thus with his divine eye, which is purified and surpasses the human, he sees beings passing away and reappearing, inferior and superior, fair and ugly, fortunate and unfortunate.

original: cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe, sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānāti.
analyzed: cavamāne upapajjamāne hīne paṇīte suvaṇṇe dubbaṇṇe sugate duggate yathākammūpage satte pajānāti
translated: He understands how beings pass on according to their actions.

original: Ayamassa dutiyā vijjā adhigatā hoti;
analyzed: ayam assa dutiyā vijjā adhigatā hoti
translated: This is the second knowledge he has attained.

original: avijjā vihatā, vijjā uppannā; tamo vihato, āloko uppanno yathā taṁ appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato.
analyzed: avijjā vihatā vijjā uppannā tamaḥ vihataḥ ālokaḥ uppannaḥ yathā tam appamattassa ātāpinaḥ pahitattassa viharato
translated: Ignorance is destroyed; knowledge has arisen; darkness is destroyed; light has arisen, as happens in one who dwells heedful, ardent, and resolute.

original: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte āsavānaṁ khayañāṇāya cittaṁ abhininnāmeti.
analyzed: saḥ evam samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigata upakkilese mudu bhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñja ppatte āsavānam khaya ñāṇāya cittam abhininnāmeti
translated: “When his concentrated mind is thus purified, bright, unblemished, rid of imperfection, malleable, wieldy, steady, and attained to imperturbability, he directs it to knowledge of the destruction of the taints.

original: So ‘idaṁ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti,
analyzed: saḥ idam dukkhan ti yathābhūtam pajānāti ayam dukkha samudayaḥ iti yathābhūtam pajānāti
translated: He understands as it really is: ‘This is suffering’; he understands as it really is: ‘This is the origin of suffering’;

original: ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti🔽yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti;
analyzed: ayam dukkha nirodho ti yathābhūtam pajānāti ayam dukkha nirodha gāminī paṭipadā ati  yathābhūtam pajānāti
translated: he understands as it really is: ‘This is the cessation of suffering’; he understands as it really is: ‘This is the way leading to the cessation of suffering.’

original: ‘ime āsavā’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ āsavasamudayo’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti,🔽‘ayaṁ āsavanirodho’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti, ‘ayaṁ āsavanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti
analyzed: ime āsavāḥ ti yathābhūtam pajānāti ayam āsava samudayaḥ iti yathābhūtam pajānāti  ayam āsava nirodha uti yathābhūtam pajānāti ayam āsava nirodha gāminī paṭipadā ati
translated: He understands as it really is: ‘These are the taints’; he understands as it really is: ‘This is the origin of the taints’;

original: yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti.
analyzed: yathābhūtam pajānāti
translated: he understands as it really is: ‘This is the cessation of the taints’; he understands as it really is: ‘This is the way leading to the cessation of the taints.’

original: Tassa evaṁ jānato evaṁ passato kāmāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati, bhavāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati, avijjāsavāpi cittaṁ vimuccati;
analyzed: tassa evam jānataḥ evam passataḥ kāma āsavā api cittam vimuccati bhava āsavā api cittam vimuccati avijjā āsavā api cittam vimuccati
translated: When he knows and sees thus, his mind is liberated from the taint of sensual desire, from the taint of being, and from the taint of ignorance.

original: vimuttasmiṁ vimuttamiti ñāṇaṁ hoti.
analyzed: vimuttasmin vimuttam iti ñāṇam hoti
translated: When it is liberated there comes the knowledge: ‘It is liberated.’

original: ‘Khīṇā jāti, vusitaṁ brahmacariyaṁ, kataṁ karaṇīyaṁ, nāparaṁ itthattāyā’ti pajānāti.
analyzed: brahmacariya katam karaṇīya na aparam itthattāya ati pajānāti
translated: He understands: ‘Birth is destroyed, the holy life has been lived, what had to be done has been done, there is no more coming to any state of being.’

original: Ayamassa tatiyā vijjā adhigatā hoti;
analyzed: ayam assa tatiyā vijjā adhigatā hoti
translated: This is his third knowledge. He attains the destruction of the taints.

original: avijjā vihatā, vijjā uppannā; tamo vihato, āloko uppanno yathā taṁ appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharatoti.
analyzed: avijjā vihatā vijjā uppannā tamaḥ vihataḥ ālokaḥ uppannaḥ yathā tam appamattassa ātāpinaḥ pahitattassa viharato ti
translated: ignorance was abandoned, and knowledge arose; darkness was abandoned, and light arose — as happens in one who abides diligent, ardent, and resolute.”

original: Anuccāvacasīlassa,
analyzed: an uccāvaca sīlassa
translated: “The one who is skilled in the training,

original: nipakassa ca jhāyino;
analyzed: nipakassa ca jhāyinaḥ
translated: alert, and a meditator,

original: Cittaṁ yassa vasībhūtaṁ,🔽ekaggaṁ susamāhitaṁ.🔽Taṁ ve tamonudaṁ dhīraṁ,
analyzed: cittam yassa vasībhūta  ekaggam su samāhita  tam veḥ tamonudam dhīra
translated: who has gained control over his mind,🔽one-pointed, well concentrated,🔽the one who has dispelled darkness,

original: tevijjaṁ maccuhāyinaṁ;
analyzed: tevijjam maccuhāyina
translated: the wise one with threefold knowledge, the conqueror of death,

original: Hitaṁ devamanussānaṁ,
analyzed: hitam deva manussāna
translated: beneficial to gods and men,

original: āhu sabbappahāyinaṁ.
analyzed: āhu sabba ppahāyina
translated: they call him one who has given up everything.

original: Tīhi vijjāhi sampannaṁ,
analyzed: tīhi vijjāhi sampanna
translated: Endowed with the three knowledges,

original: asammūḷhavihārinaṁ;
analyzed: asammūḍhavihārina
translated: dwelling without confusion,

original: Buddhaṁ antimadehinaṁ,
analyzed: buddham antimadehina
translated: the Buddha, the one with final knowledge,

original: taṁ namassanti gotamaṁ.
analyzed: tam namassanti gotama
translated: they honor the one named Gotama.

original: Pubbenivāsaṁ yo vedī,
analyzed: pubbenivāsam yaḥ vedī
translated: One who has understood past lives,🔽who sees heaven and the plane of woe,

original: saggāpāyañca passati;🔽Atho jātikkhayaṁ patto,
analyzed: sagga apāyañca passati  atho jāti khayam patto
translated: and has attained the destruction of birth,

original: abhiññāvosito muni.
analyzed: abhiññā vositaḥ muni
translated: the sage perfected in direct knowledge,

original: Etāhi tīhi vijjāhi,
analyzed: etāhi tīhi vijjāhi
translated: with these three knowledges

original: tevijjo hoti brāhmaṇo;
analyzed: tevijjaḥ hoti brāhmaṇaḥ
translated: he is a brahmin with threefold knowledge.

original: Tamahaṁ vadāmi tevijjaṁ,
analyzed: tam aham vadāmi tevijja
translated: I call him one with threefold knowledge,

original: nāññaṁ lapitalāpananti.
analyzed: na aññam lapita lāpananti
translated: not one who just prattles on.”

original: Evaṁ kho, brāhmaṇa, ariyassa vinaye tevijjo hotī”ti.
analyzed: evam kho brāhmaṇa ariyassa vinaye tevijjaḥ hoti iti
translated: “It is in this way, brahmin, that one is a person with threefold knowledge in the Noble One’s discipline.”

original: “Aññathā, bho gotama, brāhmaṇānaṁ tevijjo, aññathā ca pana ariyassa vinaye tevijjo hoti.
analyzed: aññathā bho gotama brāhmaṇānam tevijjaḥ aññathā ca pana ariyassa vinaye tevijjaḥ hoti
translated: “The one who is learned in the three Vedas as described by the brahmins, Master Gotama, is not the one who is learned in the three knowledges in the Noble One’s discipline.

original: Imassa ca pana, bho gotama, ariyassa vinaye tevijjassa brāhmaṇānaṁ tevijjo kalaṁ nāgghati soḷasiṁ.
analyzed: imassa ca pana bho gotama ariyassa vinaye tevijjassa brāhmaṇānam tevijjaḥ kalam na agghati soḷasi
translated: The one who is learned in the three knowledges in the Noble One’s discipline is not even a sixteenth part of the one who is learned in the three Vedas as described by the brahmins.

original: Abhikkantaṁ, bho gotama …pe…
analyzed: abhikkanta bho gotama pe
translated: Excellent, Master Gotama! …

original: upāsakaṁ maṁ bhavaṁ gotamo dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetaṁ saraṇaṁ gatan”ti.🔽Aṭṭhamaṁ.
analyzed: upāsakam mam bhavam gotamaḥ dhāretu ajjatagge pāṇupetam saraṇam gatanti  aṭṭhama
translated: From this day forth, may Master Gotama remember me as a lay follower who has gone for refuge for life.”🔽The eighth section on the one learned in the three Vedas is finished.

original: Aṅguttara Nikāya 3.59
analyzed: aṅguttara nikāya
translated: The Book of the Elevens

original: 6. Brāhmaṇavagga
analyzed: brāhmaṇa vagga
translated: The Brahmins

original: Jāṇussoṇisutta
analyzed: jāṇussoṇisutta
translated: With Jāṇussoṇi

original: Atha kho jāṇussoṇi brāhmaṇo yena bhagavā tenupasaṅkami; upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhiṁ …pe… ekamantaṁ nisinno kho jāṇussoṇi brāhmaṇo bhagavantaṁ etadavoca:
analyzed: atha khalu jāṇussoṇiḥ brāhmaṇaḥ yena bhagavā tena upasaṅkami upasaṅkamitvā bhagavatā saddhim pe ekamantam nisinnaḥ khalu jāṇussoṇiḥ brāhmaṇaḥ bhagavantam etat avoca
translated: Then the brahmin Jāṇussoṇi went to the Buddha and exchanged greetings with him. … He sat down and said to the Buddha,

original: “yassassu, bho gotama, yañño vā saddhaṁ vā thālipāko vā deyyadhammaṁ vā, tevijjesu brāhmaṇesu dānaṁ dadeyyā”ti.
analyzed: bho gotama yaññaḥ vā saddham vā thālipākaḥ vā deyya dhammam vā tevijjesu brāhmaṇesu dānam dadeyya ati
translated: “If anyone has a sacrifice or a meal for the gods or a funeral feast or an offering for departed relatives or a gift for virtuous people, they should give it to brahmins learned in the three Vedas.”

original: “Yathā kathaṁ pana, brāhmaṇa, brāhmaṇā tevijjaṁ paññapentī”ti?
analyzed: yathā katham pana brāhmaṇa brāhmaṇā tevijjam paññapenti iti
translated: “But, brahmin, how do the brahmins describe the one who is learned in the three Vedas?”

original: “Idha kho, bho gotama, brāhmaṇo ubhato sujāto hoti mātito ca pitito ca saṁsuddhagahaṇiko
analyzed: idha khalu bho gotama brāhmaṇaḥ ubhatas su jātaḥ hoti mātitaḥ ca pititaḥ ca sa suddha gahaṇikaḥ
translated: “Here, Master Gotama, a brahmin is well born on both sides, of pure maternal and paternal descent seven generations back,

original: yāva sattamā pitāmahayugā akkhitto anupakkuṭṭho jātivādena, ajjhāyako mantadharo,
analyzed: yāva sattamā pitāmaha yugā akkhittaḥ an upakkuṭṭhaḥ jāti vādena ajjhāyakaḥ manta dharo
translated: “Master Gotama, a brahmin is well-born on both his mother’s and his father’s side, of pure descent to the seventh generation, unassailable and impeccable with respect to birth.

original: tiṇṇaṁ vedānaṁ pāragū sanighaṇḍukeṭubhānaṁ sākkharappabhedānaṁ itihāsapañcamānaṁ,
analyzed: tiṇṇam vedānam pāragū sa nighaṇḍu keṭubhānam sa akkhara ppabhedānam itihāsa pañcamānam
translated: He has memorized the hymns and has mastered the three Vedas together with their vocabularies, liturgy, phonology, and etymology, and the histories as a fifth; he knows philology and grammar and is well-versed in cosmology.

original: padako, veyyākaraṇo, lokāyatamahāpurisalakkhaṇesu anavayoti.
analyzed: padakaḥ veyyākaraṇaḥ lokāyata mahāpurisa lakkhaṇesu
translated: He is complete with this virtue.

original: Evaṁ kho, bho gotama, brāhmaṇā tevijjaṁ paññapentī”ti.
analyzed: evam kho bho gotama brāhmaṇā tevijjam paññapenti iti
translated: This is how the brahmins describe a brahmin of the threefold knowledge.”

original: “Aññathā kho, brāhmaṇa, brāhmaṇā brāhmaṇaṁ tevijjaṁ paññapenti, aññathā ca pana ariyassa vinaye tevijjo hotī”ti.
analyzed: aññathā kho brāhmaṇa brāhmaṇāḥ brāhmaṇam tevijjam paññapenti aññathā ca pana ariyassa vinaye tevijjaḥ hoti iti
translated: “Brahmins describe a brahmin of the threefold knowledge in one way, but in the Noble One’s discipline a person of the threefold knowledge is different.”

original: “Yathā kathaṁ pana, bho gotama, ariyassa vinaye tevijjo hoti?
analyzed: yathā katham pana bho gotama ariyassa vinaye tevijjaḥ hoti
translated: “But, Master Gotama, how is a person of the threefold knowledge in the Noble One’s discipline described?

original: Sādhu me bhavaṁ gotamo tathā dhammaṁ desetu yathā ariyassa vinaye tevijjo hotī”ti.
analyzed: sādhu me bhavam gotamaḥ tathā dhammam desetu yathā ariyassa vinaye tevijjaḥ hoti iti
translated: It would be good if Master Gotama were to teach me the Dhamma so that I might know how a person of the threefold knowledge is described in the Noble One’s discipline.”

original: “Tena hi, brāhmaṇa, suṇāhi, sādhukaṁ manasi karohi; bhāsissāmī”ti.
analyzed: tena hi brāhmaṇa suṇāhi sādhukam manasi karohi bhāsissāmi iti
translated: “Then listen and attend closely to what I shall say.”

original: “Evaṁ, bho”ti kho jāṇussoṇi brāhmaṇo bhagavato paccassosi.
analyzed: eva bhoti kho jāṇussoṇi brāhmaṇaḥ bhagavataḥ paccassosi
translated: “Yes, sir,” replied Jānussoṇi.

original: Bhagavā etadavoca:
analyzed: bhagavān etat avoca
translated: The Buddha said this:

original: “Idha pana, brāhmaṇa, bhikkhu vivicceva kāmehi …pe…
analyzed: idha pana brāhmaṇa bhikkhu vivicca iva kāmehi pe
translated: “Here, brahmin, a bhikkhu, quite secluded from sensual pleasures, secluded from unwholesome states,

original: catutthaṁ jhānaṁ upasampajja viharati.
analyzed: catuttham jhānam upasampajja viharati
translated: enters and dwells in the first jhāna, which consists of rapture and pleasure born of seclusion, accompanied by thought and examination.

original: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte pubbenivāsānussatiñāṇāya cittaṁ abhininnāmeti.
analyzed: saḥ evam samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigata upakkilese mudu bhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñja ppatte pubbenivāsa anussati ñāṇāya cittam abhininnāmeti
translated: When his concentrated mind is thus purified, bright, unblemished, rid of imperfection, malleable, wieldy, steady, and attained to imperturbability, he directs it to knowledge of the recollection of past lives.

original: So anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati, seyyathidaṁ—ekampi jātiṁ dvepi jātiyo …pe… iti sākāraṁ sauddesaṁ anekavihitaṁ pubbenivāsaṁ anussarati.🔽Ayamassa paṭhamā vijjā adhigatā hoti;
analyzed: so aneka vihitam pubbenivāsam anussarati sa iyyathida ekam pi jātim dve pi jātiyaḥ pe iti sa ākāram sa uddesam aneka vihitam pubbenivāsam anussarati  ayam assa paṭhamā vijjā adhigatā hoti
translated: He recollects his manifold past lives, that is, one birth, two five, ten fifty, a hundred, a thousand, a hundred thousand, many eons of cosmic contraction, many eons of cosmic expansion, many eons of cosmic contraction and expansion: ‘There I had such a name, belonged to such a clan, had such an appearance. Such was my food, such my sensitivity, such my experience of pleasure and pain, such the end of my life. Passing away from that state, I re-arose there. There too I had such a name, belonged to such a clan, had such an appearance. Such was my food, such my sensitivity, such my experience of pleasure and pain, such the end of my life. Passing away from that state, I re-arose here.’ Thus he remembers his manifold past lives in their modes and details.

original: avijjā vihatā, vijjā uppannā; tamo vihato, āloko uppanno yathā taṁ appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato.
analyzed: avijjā vihatā vijjā uppannā tamaḥ vihataḥ ālokaḥ uppannaḥ yathā tam appamattassa ātāpinaḥ pahitattassa viharato
translated: This is the first knowledge attained by him; ignorance is abandoned by him; knowledge has arisen; darkness has been destroyed; light has arisen, as happens in one who dwells diligent, ardent, and resolute.

original: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte sattānaṁ cutūpapātañāṇāya cittaṁ abhininnāmeti.
analyzed: saḥ evam samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigata upakkilese mudu bhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñja ppatte sattānam cutūpapāta ñāṇāya cittam abhininnāmeti
translated: When his concentrated mind was purified, bright, unblemished, free from imperfection, malleable, workable, steady, and attained to imperturbability, he directed it to knowledge of the passing away and reappearance of beings.

original: So dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkantamānusakena …pe… yathākammūpage satte pajānāti.
analyzed: so dibbena cakkhunā visuddhena atikkanta mānusakena pe yathā kamma upage satte pajānāti
translated: With the divine eye, which is purified and surpasses the human, he saw beings passing away and reappearing, inferior and superior, fair and ugly, fortunate and unfortunate. He understood how beings pass on according to their actions thus:

original: Ayamassa dutiyā vijjā adhigatā hoti;
analyzed: ayam assa dutiyā vijjā adhigatā hoti
translated: This was the second knowledge he attained in the second watch of the night.

original: avijjā vihatā, vijjā uppannā; tamo vihato, āloko uppanno yathā taṁ appamattassa ātāpino pahitattassa viharato.
analyzed: avijjā vihatā vijjā uppannā tamaḥ vihataḥ ālokaḥ uppannaḥ yathā tam appamattassa ātāpinaḥ pahitattassa viharato
translated: Ignorance was destroyed; knowledge arose; darkness was destroyed; light arose—as happens in one who is heedful, ardent, and resolute.

original: So evaṁ samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigatūpakkilese mudubhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñjappatte āsavānaṁ khayañāṇāya cittaṁ abhininnāmeti.
analyzed: saḥ evam samāhite citte parisuddhe pariyodāte anaṅgaṇe vigata upakkilese mudu bhūte kammaniye ṭhite āneñja ppatte āsavānam khaya ñāṇāya cittam abhininnāmeti
translated: When his concentrated mind was purified, bright, unblemished, free from imperfection, malleable, workable, steady, and attained to imperturbability, he directed it to knowledge of the destruction of the taints.

original: So ‘idaṁ dukkhan’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti …pe… ‘ayaṁ dukkhanirodhagāminī paṭipadā’ti yathābhūtaṁ pajānāti;
analyzed: saḥ idam dukkhanti yathābhūtam pajānāti pe ayam dukkha nirodha gāminī paṭipadā ati yathābhūtam pajānāti
